utterance: Thank you for calling Debt Recovery Associates. This call is being recorded. I'm Amanda, a virtual agent. How can I help you?
I got a voicemail from this number.
I can help you with that. Can you provide your phone number?
Three zero three seven seven seven four four four four.
Let me confirm, three zero three seven seven seven four four four four?
Correct.
May I have your full name?
David Thompson.
And your date of birth?
June twenty second nineteen seventy nine.
Thank you, David. This is an attempt to collect a debt. I see there's a balance of two hundred ninety five dollars and forty cents on your account. Would you be able to resolve this today?
What is this debt for?
This is from a utility account with Mountain View Electric that was sent to collections in August of this year. Does that sound familiar?
Oh yeah, from my old apartment. I thought I paid that when I moved out.
It's possible there was a final bill that came after you moved. The balance shows as unpaid from your final billing cycle.
I see. So it's two hundred ninety five dollars?
Yes, two hundred ninety five dollars and forty cents.
Not today. I just wanted to know what this was about. I don't have money right now.
I understand. Can I ask, are you currently employed?
I'm between jobs right now. That's why money is tight.
I completely understand. A lot of people go through that. When do you expect to be back to work?
I'm not sure. I've been applying to places but haven't heard back yet.
That can be stressful. Are you receiving any unemployment benefits during this time?
No, I didn't qualify for that.
I see. Well, we do want to work with you. Even though you can't pay today, is there any amount you might be able to put toward this in the near future? Even a small payment can help.
I really don't have anything right now. I'm barely covering rent and food.
I understand your situation. Is there a better time we could call you back to discuss payment options, maybe in a few weeks when things might be more stable?
Maybe in a couple weeks. I'm hoping to have something lined up by then.
That sounds reasonable. We also have payment plan options that could make this easier when you are ready. We could break this into smaller monthly payments if that would help.
How small are we talking?
For a balance of two hundred ninety five dollars, we could do payments as low as fifty dollars a month over six months. Would something like that be manageable when you're working again?
Yeah, fifty a month would be doable once I'm employed.
Perfect. So when we talk in a couple of weeks, we can set that up if you're ready at that point. Should I have someone call you back in two weeks?
Yeah, that works.
Okay, I'll schedule a callback for two weeks from today. And David, just so you know, we'll probably be sending you written notices as well. Those are standard procedure.
That's fine. What address do you have on file?
Let me check. I show an address on Mountain Ridge Drive in Boulder. Is that still current?
No, I moved. My new address is twelve thirty four Maple Street, Apartment B, Denver, Colorado, eight zero two zero two.
Thank you. Let me update that. Twelve thirty four Maple Street, Apartment B, Denver, Colorado, eight zero two zero two. Is that correct?
Yes, that's right.
Perfect. I've updated your address in our system. You should receive correspondence at that address now.
Okay, good.
Is there a best time of day to reach you when we call back in two weeks?
Probably afternoons are better, after one PM.
Got it. I'll make a note that afternoons after one PM are preferable. And is this phone number the best one to reach you?
Yes, this is my cell.
Perfect. David, I want you to know that we're here to help. When you're ready, we'll work with you to set up something manageable. Is there anything else I can help you with today?
No, that's all.
Alright. I hope your job search goes well, and we'll reach out in two weeks. Take care, David.
Thanks. Bye.
Thank you for calling. Goodbye.
